results.title: Family stress: the child's perspective
results.creator_credit: George A. Colburn, Darrel Schwandt, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Examines the social and economic forces that alter families and increase risks for children. Reviews research results on the effects of divorce on children, observing a Russian family on the brink of divorce. The determinants and outcomes of teen pregnancy are discussed with American teen mothers and mothers-to-be.

results.title: Family recreation
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Shell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Live”.
Australians in most walks of life now have more leisure time at their disposal. There are many enjoyable, interesting and healthy ways of utilising this leisure time, and this film gives many suggestions - and much food for thought.

results.title: Family reactions
results.creator_credit: Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit, Tony Shaddock, Helen Edwards and Tim Abbott
results.brief_description: Designed to provide the intellectual disability residential care worker with an insight into what it means to be part of a family that includes a child with developmental disabilities, an understanding of the grieving process and how families cope, an appreciation of the needs of different families, to learn ways of interacting positively with parents, to examine methods of developing effective partnerships with parents and most importantly develop an appreciation of the uniqueness of families and their reactions. Accompanied by 44p. in-service training manual.

results.title: Family portrait
results.brief_description: An impression, by the late Humphrey Jennings, poet, painter and film maker, of the spirit and traditions of Britain and its people. Made in celebration of the Festival of Britain, 1951. Credits include: music by John Greenwood; photography by Martin Curtis; narration by Michael Goodliffe; music direction by conductor Muir Mathieson.

results.title: Family plot [DVD]
results.brief_description: Two parallel plots run through Alfred Hitchcock’s final film. In one strand, a phoney medium and her cabbie boyfriend are hired by an unsuspecting elderly woman to help locate her long lost nephew heir. In the other tale, an equally sinister couple, a jeweller and his girlfriend, have kidnapped a rich Greek shipping magnate and are hoping to be paid a ransom in diamonds. The two stories intersect in a brilliant move of comic direction which finds them both at the cemetery. Cast includes Karen Black, Bruce Dern, Barbara Harris and William Devane. Screenplay by Ernest Lehman, based on the novel “The Rainbird pattern” by Victor Canning. Cinematography by Leonard J. South. Music by John Williams.

results.title: Family or friends...?
results.creator_credit: Timothy Sullivan, Filmhouse and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description: Children from three age groups - five to nine, nine to twelve, and thirteen to eighteen - and different socio-economic classes are interviewed about their feelings on family relationships and the bonds of friendship. Useful for units of study on family relationships, social relationships and peer pressure.

results.title: Family of man
results.brief_description: A portrayal of the “Family of Man” exhibit on display in the US in 1955 and in Australia in which Edward Steichen describes and demonstrates various exhibit panels, and explains how photography can be used as an art medium to show the universal oneness and goodness of mankind.

results.title: Family of chimps
results.brief_description: A documentary recording the day-to-day activities of a chimpanzee family living in an open enclosure surrounded by a moat at Burgers Zoo in Arnheim. Scientists and the public observe their behaviour unobtrusively from a distance.

results.title: Family matters
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Facts for Life”.
Explains the transition from life in the womb to life after birth. Shows care of premature babies and stresses the importance of mother-child contact. Discusses mental milestones of the first 18 months and comments on the mother’s feelings of being on duty for 24 hours a day.

results.title: Family matters
results.creator_credit: Jenny Drew and Robert Van der Vvyer
results.brief_description: The twelve months after the first baby arrives can be a crucial time in a couple’s relationship. The twosome becomes a threesome, and much of a couple’s time and energy is directed towards caregiving, with possible misunderstandings and resentments occurring if each partner does not understand how the other is feeling.
